newsitem.title: USA: Neoprobe technology approved in S. Korea.
newsitem.headline: Neoprobe technology approved in S. Korea.

text.p: Neoprobe Corp on Monday said its RIGScan technology for use in cancer surgery received marketing approval in South Korea.
Neoprobe said it expected to begin shipment of its RIGScan CR49 in the first quarter. The technology is expected to be used initially for surgery for metastatic colorectal cancer.

RIGS technology involves injecting patients before surgery with a low-energy radioactive drug that targets cancer cells. Surgeons then use a handheld gamma-detecting probe to locate tissue containing significant amounts of the targeting agent.
Neoprobe said it may eventually be used for other cancers.
It has been used in research on stomach and pancreatic cancers, Neoprobe said.
The company is also seeking regulatory approvals in the U.S., Europe and elsewhere.
"This is an exciting first step toward the worldwide commercialization of our RIGS surgical detection products," Neoprobe President David Bupp said in a statement.

Neoprobe's Korean marketing and distribution partner, Damon Pharm Ltd, has begun promoting RIGScan CR49 in Korea and also has marketing and distribution rights in Malaysia, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand, Neoprobe said.
